author: By Alex Marshall
title: Britain Memorializes a Queen, With Smiles and Bronze Corgis
description: Sculptors have immortalized past British monarchs with imposing, stern-faced statues. For Queen Elizabeth II, they’re taking a different approach.
content: It looked like a corgi convention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbie VanSickle
title: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Uphold Local Bans on Homeless Encampments
description: A majority of the justices appeared skeptical of courts wading into the thorny policy questions around when local governments can punish people for sleeping and camping outdoors.
content: A majority of the Supreme Court appeared inclined on Monday to uphold a series of local ordinances that allowed a small Oregon city to ban homeless people from sleeping or camping in public spaces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Some of the ‘Adults in the Room’ Aren’t Who We Thought They Would Be
description: Who let the grown-ups out?
content: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. I think the theme for last week was the return of adult supervision. Mike Johnson, the speaker of the House, finally showed a spine by staring down Marjorie Taylor Greene and joining forces with Democrats to pass critical foreign aid bills. And Minouche Shafik, the president of Columbia University, authorized the police to arrest pro-Palestinian student protesters who had occupied part of the campus in violation of university policies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck, Anjali Huynh and Jeff Swensen
title: Summer Lee Has Been a Vocal Israel Critic. Will It Matter in Her Primary?
description: The race in Pennsylvania once seemed primed to become a major test of Democratic attitudes about the Middle East. But in much of the district, an expected ideological battle has not arrived.
content: As a progressive insurgent in her last primary campaign, Summer Lee barely eked out a victory in a Pittsburgh-area congressional race, facing fierce opposition from local Democratic leadership and an onslaught of spending from outside groups.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Callahan
title: A Novel of Lost Daughters and Waylaid Lives
description: Prison, pregnancies and other operatic turns propel Caroline Leavitt’s latest book, “Days of Wonder.”
content: When the unfairness of life overwhelms you, does it bring out your grit and resolve, or send you down a rabbit hole of grievance and desperation?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch and Jordyn Holman
title: F.T.C. Sues to Block $8.5 Billion Fashion Merger
description: The deal between Coach’s owner, Tapestry, and the parent of Michael Kors, Capri Holdings, is intended to create a U.S. luxury group to compete with the European industry giants.
content: The Federal Trade Commission on Monday sued to block Tapestry’s $8.5 billion acquisition of Capri, a blockbuster fashion tie-up that would bring together Coach, Kate Spade, Michael Kors and Versace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: ‘Patriots’ Review: What Happened to the Man Who Made Putin?
description: Michael Stuhlbarg and Will Keen shine as a kingmaker and his creature. But in Peter Morgan’s cheesy-fun play, it’s not always clear which is which.
content: “In the West you have no idea.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Mervosh
title: Here’s What Is Happening on Some Other Campuses Across the Country
description: Demonstrations appeared to be unfolding mainly at universities in the Northeast, although protests spread to some other campuses.
content: The fallout from last week’s heated congressional hearing and subsequent arrests at Columbia University continued to reverberate at several colleges and universities on Monday, as students erected tents and staged their own rallies and sit-ins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Cheney
title: Liz Cheney: The Supreme Court Should Rule Swiftly on Trump’s Immunity Claim
description: If delay prevents this Trump case from being tried this year, our system may never hold the man most responsible for Jan. 6 to account.
content: On Thursday, the U.S. Supreme Court will hear Donald Trump’s arguments that he is immune from prosecution for his efforts to steal the 2020 presidential election. It is likely that all — or nearly all — of the justices will agree that a former president who attempted to seize power and remain in office illegally can be prosecuted. I suspect that some justices may also wish to clarify whether doctrines of presidential immunity might apply in other contexts — for example, to a president’s actions as commander in chief during a time of war. But the justices should also recognize the profoundly negative impact they may have if the court does not resolve these issues quickly and decisively.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Overflowing, Amsterdam Adopts a Ban of New Hotels
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, April 22, 2024.
content: “Without such a stop, Amsterdam’s center would become one big hotel.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 316
description: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: Ukraine War Helped Push World Military Spending to 35-Year High, Study Says
description: The outlay reached $2.4 trillion last year, a research group found, 6.8 percent up on 2022. Tensions in Asia and the Middle East also contributed.
content: The world spent more on military costs and weapons in 2023 than it had in 35 years, driven in part by the war in Ukraine and the threat of an expanded Russian invasion, according to an independent analysis released on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Rikki Novetsky, Nina Feldman, Eric Krupke, Alex Stern, Lisa Chow, Patricia Willens, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell, Rowan Niemisto, Sophia Lanman and Chris Wood
title: The Evolving Danger of the New Bird Flu
description: An unusual outbreak of the disease has spread to dairy herds in multiple U.S. states.
content: The outbreak of bird flu currently tearing through the nation’s poultry is the worst in U.S. history. Scientists say it is now spreading beyond farms into places and species it has never been before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: Networks Covering Trump’s Trial Are Forced to Get Creative
description: TV networks began the challenging assignment on Monday of covering former President Trump’s trial without the luxury of cameras inside the courtroom.
content: A little after 10:30 a.m., just as a prosecutor began delivering his opening statement in Donald J. Trump’s Manhattan criminal trial, CNN’s chief legal correspondent, Paula Reid, had a live on-air update.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: Clashing Visions of Trump
description: The prosecution and the defense presented their opening statements.
content: After a year of legal skirmishes and a week of jury selection, today marked the true beginning of the first prosecution of a former American president — a courtroom drama complete with lawyerly broadsides, a no-nonsense judge and 12 Manhattanites sitting in judgment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Marc Santora, Ian Stewart, Jessica Metzger and James Shield
title: The Trump Trial Ramps Up, and the Supreme Court Considers A Homelessness Case
description: Plus, a swimming scandal.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh
title: Progressive Allies Rally With Pittsburgh Congresswoman as Primary Looms
description: Summer Lee, the first Black woman to represent Pennsylvania in the House, got help from Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Justin Jones as she faced criticism over her stance on Gaza.
content: A high-energy crowd rallied on Sunday in Pittsburgh to support Representative Summer Lee, a left-leaning congresswoman whose primary on Tuesday is a high-profile test whether she can stave off a challenge aimed in part at her stance over the war in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley and Kate Christobek
title: Opening Statements in Trump’s Criminal Trial: Five Takeaways
description: Prosecutors signaled a sweeping case and Donald J. Trump’s lawyers began their assault on witnesses’ credibility. The judge seems intent on expediting the first trial of an American president.
content: Monday marked another key moment in the criminal trial of Donald J. Trump: opening statements, during which the former president listened quietly to the prosecution’s allegations of crimes, and the defense’s counterargument that he was a simple man, wrongly accused.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Knvul Sheikh
title: Taking Multiple Medications? You May Need to Scale Back.
description: Many people in the United States are taking five or more prescription drugs. That can lead to serious complications.
content: Around one in five adults between the ages of 40 to 79 is taking five or more prescription drugs, according to data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. And the older patients are, the more likely it is they’re taking even more medications.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ricci Shryock
title: A Remote Island Draws Thousands of Turtles Each Year. Could It Attract Tourists?
description: Green sea turtles swim hundreds of miles to nest on a spectacular West African archipelago. Getting there is quite a journey for humans, too.
content: Each year, thousands of baby green sea turtles clamber across a beautiful, white-sand paradise that is one of the largest hatching sites of this species in the Atlantic, adorably making their way to the sea. There’s one noticeable absence: people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: As Floods Beckoned, Many of New York’s Catch-Basin Trucks Were Offline
description: A report by the New York City comptroller’s office found “big gaps” in how the administration of Mayor Eric Adams handles emergency preparations.
content: Seven months after New York City was inundated by more than eight inches of rain, an investigation found that the city’s public communications were, in some cases, “woefully limited” and its infrastructure inadequate to the challenges of extreme weather.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court to Hear Challenge to Biden’s Limits on ‘Ghost Guns’
description: The Supreme Court temporarily revived the regulations in August by a 5-to-4 vote after lower courts blocked them.
content: The Supreme Court agreed on Monday to hear a challenge to the Biden administration’s regulation of “ghost guns” — kits that can be bought online and assembled into untraceable homemade firearms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Cher, Dave Matthews Band and A Tribe Called Quest Join Rock Hall of Fame
description: Mary J. Blige and Ozzy Osbourne were also voted in, but Sinead O’Connor, who died last year at 56, did not make the cut.
content: Cher, Ozzy Osbourne, Peter Frampton and Mary J. Blige are part of the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame’s class of 2024, along with Dave Matthews Band, Kool & the Gang, Foreigner and A Tribe Called Quest, the hall announced on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquín
title: Lourdes Portillo, Oscar-Nominated Documentary Filmmaker, Dies at 80
description: Her films centered on Latin American experiences and received wide acclaim.
content: Lourdes Portillo, an Oscar-nominated Mexican-born documentary filmmaker whose work explored Latin American social issues, died on Saturday at her home in San Francisco. She was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr, Melissa Guerrero and Jutharat Pinyodoonyachet
title: Eddie Redmayne and Angela Bassett Journey to Berlin at ‘Cabaret’ Opening
description: A party for the buzzy revival of the Broadway musical was held at a theater that has been transformed to look like a 1930s-era nightclub.
content: “I’m so ready for this,” said the actress Bernadette Peters on Saturday afternoon as she stood on the red carpet outside the August Wilson Theater on 52nd Street, which had been styled to look like a Berlin nightclub in the 1930s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Everything You Need to Know About the 2024 Met Gala
description: What’s the dress code, who’s hosting, who’s going and how to watch.
content: First things first: What is the Met Gala?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Anderson
title: Behind a Vegan Chef’s Holistic Empire, an Ugly Reality
description: Matthew Kenney, one of the most famous names in plant-based cuisine, has left a trail of burned investors, bounced paychecks and graphic text messages.
content: Josie Duran overheard Matthew Kenney’s pitch many times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The International Herald Tribune
title: 1974: Leftists Threaten to Kill Official in Genoa Kidnap
description: A man claiming to represent members of a group called the Red Brigades said that they would kill the Italian city’s deputy public prosecutor unless an imprisoned bank robber was released.
content: ROME — A man claiming to represent the kidnappers of Genoa’s deputy public prosecutor threatened tonight to kill him unless an imprisoned bank robber was released.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Reyburn
title: For Sale: A Rare Klimt Portrait, Valued at $32 Million. But of Whom?
description: The painting’s re-emergence after decades has come with a swirl of questions about its subject, one of three related teenage girls.
content: On Wednesday, an auction house in Europe will put a painting by Gustav Klimt up for sale, with a preauction estimate of at least 30 million euros (about $32 million).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman and Patrick Kingsley
title: Israel Planned Bigger Attack on Iran, but Scaled It Back to Avoid War
description: The strike on Iran on Friday was originally intended to be much broader in scope, but after intense pressure from allies, Israeli leaders agreed to ratchet it down.
content: Israel abandoned plans for a much more extensive counterstrike on Iran after concerted diplomatic pressure from the United States and other foreign allies and because the brunt of an Iranian assault on Israel soil had been thwarted, according to three senior Israeli officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: The First Prosecution of a President Was Laid Out in Court
description: Also, pro-Palestinian protests disrupt top college campuses. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
content: A New York prosecutor today debuted the state’s case against Donald Trump to the jury of Manhattan residents that will be asked to render a verdict in about six weeks. During a 45-minute opening statement, the prosecutor detailed a scandalous story in which he accused the former president of engaging in a “criminal conspiracy” to cover up three sex scandals that threatened Trump’s 2016 campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Christobek
title: Meet the Team Prosecuting Donald J. Trump
description: Manhattan’s district attorney assembled a group of experienced courtroom hands, some of whom have confronted the former president before.
content: The Manhattan district attorney, Alvin L. Bragg, has assembled an accomplished team to take on perhaps the most high-profile case in his office’s history: the first criminal trial against former President Donald J. Trump. The group includes veteran prosecutors and former white-collar criminal defense lawyers who have extensive experience going up against Mr. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brendan Buck
title: The Freedom Caucus Started Believing in the Myth of Its Own Power
description: Ironically, the most conservative voices in the House are getting shut out.
content: On Saturday the House of Representatives approved the most consequential legislation of this Congress, a foreign aid package for American allies. More Democrats than Republicans voted in favor of the measure that allowed the package to pass. And once again the speaker’s job is at risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Christobek
title: Todd Blanche Leads the Team Defending Trump in His Criminal Hush-Money Trial
description: Mr. Blanche is also representing the former president in his federal classified documents case in Florida and his federal election interference case in Washington.
content: Donald J. Trump has assembled a team of defense lawyers with extensive experience representing people charged with white-collar crimes to defend him against the charges filed by the Manhattan district attorney’s office. Some have worked for Mr. Trump for years. Others are more recent additions, but are involved in the former president’s broader legal defense, also representing him in other criminal cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: Do You Spend Enough Time in the Dirt?
description: Scientists say that feeling the earth can be good for our bodies and minds. When was the last time you got your hands dirty?
content: How often do you spend time in the dirt?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times and Troy Closson
title: Scenes of Protests Spread at Elite Campuses
description: The arrests of more than 100 protesters at Columbia last week led to more campus demonstrations, at Yale, M.I.T. and as far away as the University of Michigan.
content: Protests and arrests spread across some of America’s most influential universities on Monday, as administrators struggled to defuse tensions on campuses over pro-Palestinian demonstrations on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Lori and George Schappell, Long-Surviving Conjoined Twins, Die at 62
description: They were distinct people who pursued different lives. “Get past this already, everybody,” Lori said, “get past it and learn to know the individual person.”
content: Lori and George Schappell, conjoined twins whose skulls were partly fused but who managed to lead independent lives, died on April 7 in Philadelphia. They were 62.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Schwarzbaum
title: Barbara Walters Did the Work
description: In “The Rulebreaker,” Susan Page pays tribute to a pioneering journalist who survived being both a punchline and an icon.
content: Much of the material in “The Rulebreaker: The Life and Times of Barbara Walters” has been told before, with persuasive narrative control, by the late television journalist herself in her dishy 2008 memoir, “Audition.” Don’t let that stop the reader of this thorough, compassionate biography by Susan Page: It’s a valuable document, sobering where “Audition” aimed for sassy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Knight
title: San Francisco Celebrates Its New Public Toilet
description: The town threw a party for the opening of a $1.7 million public restroom.
content: San Francisco closed the lid Sunday on the saga of a $1.7 million public restroom. To commemorate the commode’s installation, residents celebrated at a “potty party” they called the Toilet Bowl.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní, Colbi Edmonds and Liset Cruz
title: Some Jewish Students Are Targeted as Protests Continue at Columbia
description: After reports of harassment by demonstrators, some Jewish students said they felt unsafe. Others said they felt safe, while condemning antisemitism.
content: Days after Columbia University’s president told Congress that she would work to tamp down antisemitism, some pro-Palestinian demonstrations on and around campus veered into the harassment of Jewish students, drawing the attention of the police and the concern of a number of Jewish students.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: ‘Blair Witch Project’ Actors Push for Retroactive Royalties
description: The cast behind the 1999 horror classic was paid mere thousands for a movie that grossed almost $250 million. Now, it’s being rebooted, which was news to the actors.
content: The creative team behind the 1999 hit horror film “The Blair Witch Project” is calling for increased retroactive compensation for the movie’s three stars, as well as “meaningful consultation” on an upcoming reboot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna and Brett Anderson
title: The 25 Best Restaurants in Austin Right Now
description: There’s plenty of barbecue and Mexican — as you’d expect — but also world-class Japanese, Korean and more. Comments welcome, as always.
content: In the Where to Eat: 25 Best series, we’re highlighting our favorite restaurants in cities across the United States. These lists will be updated as restaurants close and open, and as we find new gems to recommend. As always, we pay for all of our meals and don’t accept free items.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Rothfeld
title: David Pecker Is the First Witness of Trump’s Criminal Trial
description: Mr. Pecker, the longtime publisher of The National Enquirer, is first on the stand at the former president’s trial.
content: The first witness in Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial is David Pecker, who was the publisher of The National Enquirer, and had traded favors with Mr. Trump since the 1990s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Cleveland to Pay $4.8 Million to Family of Teenager Killed in Police Pursuit
description: Tamia Chappman, 13, died in 2019 when she was struck by a stolen car driven by a youth who was trying to evade officers.
content: The city of Cleveland will pay $4.8 million to the family of a 13-year-old girl who was killed in December 2019 when she was struck by a stolen car driven by a teenage carjacker during a police pursuit, the city said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lulu Garcia-Navarro and David Marchese
title: Introducing ‘The Interview’
description: Listen to the trailer for the new weekly podcast from The New York Times.
content: “The Interview” is a new podcast from The New York Times, featuring in-depth conversations with fascinating people. Each week, David Marchese and Lulu Garcia-Navarro will chat with notable figures in the worlds of culture, politics, business, sports, wellness and beyond — illuminating who they are, why they do what they do and how they impact the rest of us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Why Aren’t We Saving the Urban Forests?
description: We have become so separate from the natural world that we don’t feel safe in the presence of well maintained trees.
content: The volunteer black walnut sapling in our front yard arrived courtesy of a local squirrel. Deep into its third spring, it looks like the kind of tree a child would draw: a narrow trunk topped by a ball of leaves. I had to mark it with a little flag to make sure my husband didn’t mow over it by accident.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton
title: What to Know About Victoria Beckham’s 50th Birthday
description: Posh Spice had a party involving tequila, Tom Cruise, Salma Hayek — and a rare performance by all five Spice Girls.
content: A 50th birthday is a major milestone in any woman’s life — though not everyone has to step into it like Victoria Beckham, who not long ago broke her foot in a gym accident. Still, Mrs. Beckham was determined to celebrate in style in London on Saturday, when, at least for one night, she replaced the medical boot she has been wearing for months with pointed toe stilettos, visible panties and a long sheer sea-foam-green gown from her own label.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess and Alan Feuer
title: Trump’s Manhattan Criminal Trial Will Not Be Televised
description: New York courts generally do not permit video to be broadcast from courtrooms, although a feed is being transmitted into an overflow room for the reporters covering the trial.
content: The Manhattan criminal trial of Donald J. Trump will be closely followed around the world. But you will not be able to watch the proceedings on TV.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone and Lila Barth
title: For Her Met Opera Debut, Lileana Blain-Cruz Directs ‘El Niño’
description: In an interview, Blain-Cruz explained why an oratorio like John Adams and Peter Sellars’s “El Niño” is more difficult to stage than the usual opera.
content: When Peter Gelb, the Metropolitan Opera’s general manager, asked the director Lileana Blain-Cruz what she wanted to stage, she didn’t need any time to think about her answer: “El Niño.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: A New Gochujang Pasta Has Entered the Chat
description: Alexa Weibel’s gochujang pasta balances the red chile paste’s pungency with sweet shrimp and juicy cherry tomatoes.
content: Get out your gochujang: Alexa Weibel has a new shrimp pasta built around the Korean red chile paste, which gives the dish so much fiery richness and depth. To make sure that the tender bits of shrimp are evenly strewed throughout the pasta, Lex smartly chops them into bite-size pieces before cooking. Cherry tomatoes add a touch of juicy sweetness, which contrasts beautifully with the gochujang’s pungency. And if you don’t have gochujang on hand, fear not; you can substitute another spicy condiment such as harissa paste, Sriracha or chile crisp.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Tuesday Briefing: The Trump Trial Opens
description: Also, a top Israeli general resigned.
content: In an opening statement, the prosecution gave a sweeping synopsis of the case against Donald Trump — a pivotal moment in the first criminal prosecution of a former American president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Bob Heil, Whose Innovations Enhanced the Sound of Rock, Dies at 83
description: A groundbreaking audio engineer, he provided the large-scale systems that brought tours by the Who and the Grateful Dead to life.
content: Bob Heil’s career as a groundbreaking sound engineer who brought thunder and rich sonic coloring to tours by rock titans like the Grateful Dead and the Who began behind a pipe organ in a 1920s movie palace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt and Tariq Panja
title: Top Biden Official Calls for Inquiry Into Chinese Doping Case
description: The administration’s top drug official, Rahul Gupta, said he would bring up the handling of Chinese swimmers’ positive tests at a meeting of sports officials this week.
content: The Biden administration’s top drug official called on Monday for an independent investigation into how Chinese and global antidoping authorities decided to clear 23 elite Chinese swimmers who tested positive for a banned drug months before the Summer Olympics in 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: How ‘Stereophonic’ Made Musicians Out of Actors
description: The new Broadway play conjures a group as dazzling as peak Fleetwood Mac. This is how five actors with limited training (one never held a bass) became rock stars.
content: About a week into rehearsals for the Off Broadway premiere of David Adjmi’s latest play, “Stereophonic,” Will Butler sent an email to the cast. Butler, a former member of Arcade Fire, had a new band, Will Butler + Sister Squares, and a new self-titled album. A club in Brooklyn would soon host the record release party. Butler, the composer of “Stereophonic,” had a proposition: The actors should open for him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Trump Was Warned to Return Records to Archives, Unsealed Documents Say
description: “Don’t give them a noble reason to indict you, because they will,” an unnamed associate told Donald J. Trump, according to an interview the person gave the F.B.I. in the classified documents case.
content: In late November 2021, as officials at the National Archives were trying to persuade former President Donald J. Trump to return a trove of records he had taken from the White House when he left office, one of Mr. Trump’s associates advised him in the sharpest terms possible to give the materials back, newly unsealed documents show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli and Emily Anthes
title: Bird Flu Is Infecting More Mammals. What Does That Mean for Us?
description: H5N1, an avian flu virus, has killed tens of thousands of marine mammals, and infiltrated American livestock for the first time. Scientists are working quickly to assess how it is evolving and how much of a risk it poses to humans.
content: In her three decades of working with elephant seals, Dr. Marcela Uhart had never seen anything like the scene on the beaches of Argentina’s Valdés Peninsula last October.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Fuhrer
title: Tutu, Bloody Tutu: Another Dangerous Ballerina Hits the Screen
description: The vampire ballerina in the new movie “Abigail” has a long pop culture lineage. She and her sisters are obsessed, tormented and likely to cause harm.
content: “Ballerina vampire”: It sounds like a particularly good Mad Libs mash-up, deliriously absurd. Even if you haven’t seen “Abigail,” the gore-fest film that premiered last week, you can probably picture the monster of its title — the fangs, the blood-spattered white tutu. Somewhere, a Spirit Halloween executive is salivating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Germany Arrests 3 Suspected of Passing Secrets to China
description: Sensitive naval data and a high-powered laser were obtained for China by three German citizens, according to prosecutors.
content: Three German citizens who are believed to have gathered sensitive naval data and obtained a high-powered laser on behalf of the Chinese security services were arrested on Monday, prosecutors said, underscoring the fragile nature of the relationship between the two countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Bidgood
title: Can Biden make Trump seem like Mitt Romney?
description: The president may be making a similar case against his wealthy rival that Obama made against the G.O.P. nominee in 2012.
content: President Biden made a populist case for re-election during his swing through Pennsylvania over three days last week, laying out plans on tariffs and taxes and seeking to burnish his working-class bona fides as a son of Scranton.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By George Gene Gustines
title: Dagwood Takes a Back Seat as Blondie Hires a Pastry Chef
description: Creators will spotlight Blondie in the comic strip, as she brings someone on board for her catering business.
content: The 93-year-old newspaper comic strip Blondie could have been called Dagwood, given how often its gags revolve around Dagwood Bumstead’s insatiable appetite, chronic lateness and his love of napping.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens and Shivani Gonzalez
title: Taylor Swift Has Given Fans a Lot. Is It Finally Too Much?
description: Swift has been inescapable over the last year. With the release of “The Tortured Poets Department,” her latest (very long) album, some seem to finally be feeling fatigued.
content: Four new studio albums. Four rerecorded albums, too. A $1 billion oxygen-sucking world tour with a concert movie to match. And, of course, one very high-profile relationship that spilled over into the Super Bowl.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich and Ben Protess
title: An Unprecedented Trial Opens With Two Visions of Trump
description: The prosecution’s opening statement sketched a seamy scheme meant to further the election of Donald J. Trump. His lawyer said the government’s case is merely “34 pieces of paper.”
content: Manhattan prosecutors delivered a raw recounting of Donald J. Trump’s seamy past on Monday as they debuted their case against him to jurors, the nation and the world, reducing the former president to a co-conspirator in a plot to cover up three sex scandals that threatened his 2016 election win.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Beloved Ostrich Dies at Kansas Zoo After Swallowing Worker’s Keys
description: Karen, a 5-year-old known for her playful antics, reached beyond her enclosure, grabbed a staff member’s keys and swallowed them, the zoo said. Attempts to save her were unsuccessful.
content: A beloved ostrich died last week after reaching beyond the confines of her Kansas zoo enclosure to grab and swallow the keys of a staff member, according to the Topeka Zoo & Conservation Center.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Mike Johnson Did the Right Thing’ on Ukraine Aid
description: Readers praise the House speaker over the passage of the aid bill. Also: A juror’s duty; banning guns; poverty and health; anxious parents and kids.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Saif Hasnat and Mike Ives
title: ‘Discomfort May Increase’: Asia’s Heat Wave Scorches Hundreds of Millions
description: April is typically hot in South and Southeast Asia, but temperatures this month have been unusually high.
content: Hundreds of millions of people in South and Southeast Asia were suffering on Monday from a punishing heat wave that has forced schools to close, disrupted agriculture, and raised the risk of heat strokes and other health complications.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd and Patrick Kingsley
title: Israel Hasn’t Offered Evidence Tying Many U.N. Workers to Hamas, Review Says
description: The review did not address whether some employees of a U.N. agency, UNRWA, took part in the Oct. 7 attack, but it said no evidence had emerged that many UNRWA workers belonged to militant groups.
content: Israel has not provided evidence to support its accusations that many employees of the main U.N. agency for Palestinian refugees are members of terrorist organizations, according to an independent review commissioned by the United Nations that was released on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Matison
title: What to Know Before Booking a National Park Trip This Summer
description: Additional routes in popular parks now require reservations, the annual pass gets a big change, Juneteenth is now a new free entrance day and more changes for 2024.
content: In 2023, the seashores, lakeshores, battlefields, historic sites, monuments and more that make up the National Park Service had 325.5 million visits, an increase of 4 percent from the year before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Brad Plumer
title: On Earth Day, Biden Spotlights Climate Investments to Contrast With Republicans
description: President Biden announced $7 billion more for solar power projects and pointed to a new a climate work force as he tries to galvanize young voters.
content: President Biden announced $7 billion in grants for solar power projects on Monday and tried to draw a contrast with Republicans who want to roll back his policies on climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: A Culture Warrior Takes a Late Swing
description: The editor and essayist Joseph Epstein looks back on his life and career in two new books.
content: When Tammy Wynette was asked to write a memoir in her mid-30s, she initially declined, she said in an interview, because “I didn’t think my life was over yet.” The publisher responded: Has it occurred to you that in 15 years no one might care? She wrote the book. “Stand by Your Man: An Autobiography” (1979) was a hit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Pickleball Gets a Permanent Spot at Wollman Rink
description: The courts are being resurfaced as the rapidly growing sport of pickleball becomes the off-season replacement for skating in Central Park.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll look at what might be called Pickleball 2.0 as the off-season replacement for skating at the Wollman Rink in Central Park. This time it’s permanent. We’ll also see what’s in the state budget that the Legislature passed over the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: 3 People Injured After Vehicle Attack in Jerusalem
description: The police arrested two men who fled the area after a car rammed into pedestrians. The Israeli authorities said the attack was an act of terrorism.
content: The Israeli authorities said they had arrested two men in Jerusalem on Monday after a vehicle was used to ram into pedestrians, injuring at least three people, in what the police called a terrorist attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Broder
title: The Far Right Wants to Take Over Europe, and She’s Leading the Way
description: Giorgia Meloni is the model for the continent’s far right.
content: “There’s just one question on voting day. Do you want an Islamized Europe or a European Europe?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Craig Foster
title: An Octopus Took My Camera, and the Images Changed the Way I See the World
description: “Saving the planet” is the wrong goal.
content: I was gifted with a new way of seeing the day I got mugged underwater. I had been filming creatures living in the Great African Sea Forest off the coast of South Africa about a year ago when my camera was grabbed straight out of my hands by a young octopus thief. Wrapping her arms around her bounty, she zoomed backward across the ocean floor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘James,’ ‘Demon Copperhead’ and the Triumph of Literary Fan Fiction
description: How Percival Everett and Barbara Kingsolver reimagined classic works by Mark Twain and Charles Dickens.
content: One of the most talked-about novels of the year so far is “James,” by Percival Everett. Last year, everyone seemed to be buzzing about Barbara Kingsolver’s “Demon Copperhead,” which won a Pulitzer Prize for fiction. These are very different books with one big thing in common: Each reimagines a beloved 19th-century masterwork, a coming-of-age story that had been a staple of youthful reading for generations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Future and Metro Boomin’s Second Joint LP Opens at No. 1
description: The Atlanta rapper and producer’s “We Still Don’t Trust You” reached the top of the Billboard 200 before the expected arrival of monster numbers from Taylor Swift next week.
content: Future and Metro Boomin, two of the big kahunas of Atlanta hip-hop, have released a pair of joint albums in the last month — wisely getting them to market ahead of Taylor Swift’s new “The Tortured Poets Department,” which has the music industry braced for gigantic sales figures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Trump will once again be in a courtroom while Biden campaigns.
description: Former President Donald J. Trump will be in New York once again this week as a criminal defendant while his opponent, President Biden, is on the campaign trail.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump will be in New York once again this week as a criminal defendant while his opponent, President Biden, is on the campaign trail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dionne Searcey
title: Is Online Shopping Bad for the Planet?
description: In theory, getting deliveries can be more efficient than driving to the store. But you may still want to think before you add to cart.
content: The convenience of online shopping is hard to beat. But it uses a lot of energy and resources and can lead to more waste.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: Generative A.I. Arrives in the Gene Editing World of CRISPR
description: Much as ChatGPT generates poetry, a new A.I. system devises blueprints for microscopic mechanisms that can edit your DNA.
content: Generative A.I. technologies can write poetry and computer programs or create images of teddy bears and videos of cartoon characters that look like something from a Hollywood movie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: On Columbia’s Campus, a Protest Encampment Grows and Tensions Flare
description: On a day the university president asked students to stay home, a tent city on a campus lawn kept growing, protesters met in tense confrontations and police and politicians converged to weigh in.
content: With a light blue academic robe tucked under her arm, Professor Marianne Hirsch hurried to get through a security line at a Columbia University entryway on Monday morning. To pass the gates, everyone had to scan IDs, in compliance with an announcement from the university’s administration that only students and faculty would be allowed on campus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: Columbia’s President May Face a Censure Resolution
description: The university senate is expected to vote as early as Wednesday on a resolution censuring Nemat Shafik, a reaction to her testimony before Congress and the arrests of student protesters.
content: In February, Nemat Shafik, the president of Columbia University, told the school’s senate that she sensed a “low level of trust” in the administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Phyllis Pressman, Luxury Superstore Matriarch, Is Dead at 95
description: She started working at Barneys to be closer to her husband. Then, she became the architect of the Chelsea Passage, the home goods bazaar that helped make it an enticing destination.
content: Phyllis Pressman, the matriarch of the family that founded Barneys New York, the discount men’s wear store turned luxury emporium — and the creator of Chelsea Passage, the store’s home goods bazaar, a pivot point in its evolution from a suit merchant to an elite lifestyle behemoth — died on Tuesday in Palm Beach, Fla. She was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: How Can Elon Musk Reassure Tesla Investors?
description: The electric vehicle maker has announced price cuts and a Cybertruck recall ahead of Tuesday’s pivotal earnings report.
content: Tesla has hardly been keeping quiet as it prepares to announce earnings on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘The Jinx Part Two’ Review: Filmmaking a Murderer
description: A new installment of HBO’s landmark true-crime documentary continues the strange, sad story of Robert Durst, in which the show is a major player.
content: Nine years after we first heard Robert Durst mutter “Killed them all, of course,” “The Jinx” is back, with a new, six-episode Part Two that premiered Sunday on HBO. And why not?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes, Adam Goldman, Eric Schmitt and Adam Rasgon
title: The Stark Reality of Israel’s Fight in Gaza
description: Israel has failed to achieve its two primary goals of the war, while the suffering of Palestinians erodes support even among its allies.
content: Israel’s military operations in Gaza have weakened Hamas. Most Hamas battalions have been degraded and are scattered. Thousands of its members have been killed, and at least one senior military leader has been eliminated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: How to Age Fingernails, and Other Tips From a Movie Makeup Book
description: Emily Schubert has done makeup and prosthetics on movies like “The Sweet East” and “Good Time.” She shares her tricks in a new book with A24.
content: Two girls on the street pointed and laughed at me. My Uber driver stared at me suspiciously. My neighbor’s eyes popped out of his head, and when my husband saw me, he begged me to remove it before date night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Delger Erdenesanaa
title: Three Places Changing Quickly to Fight Climate Change
description: Paris is becoming a city of bikes. Across China, people are snapping up $5,000 electric cars. On Earth Day, a look at a few bright spots for emission reductions.
content: Glaciers are shrinking, coral reefs are in crisis and last year was the hottest on record. Atmospheric concentrations of carbon dioxide, the main greenhouse gas, have passed a dangerous new threshold as people continue to burn fossil fuels. Is anyplace making progress on climate change?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Mdou Moctar’s Guitar Is a Screaming Siren Against Africa’s Colonial Legacy
description: “Funeral for Justice,” the musician from Niger’s album due next month, amps up the urgency in his work: “I want you to know how serious this is.”
content: “Funeral for Justice,” the new album by the African musician Mdou Moctar, opens with a blast of angry, snarling guitar and an accusation raised like a fist against the rulers of his native Niger and beyond.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: Paychecks, Drafts and Firings: The Possible Future of College Sports
description: National Labor Relations Board testimony, now in the hands of a judge, could have wide-ranging consequences — positive and negative — for athletes and their institutions.
content: As Elijah Higgins sat on a witness stand last week, he detailed the similarities between his experience last season as a rookie tight end for the Arizona Cardinals and the four years he had spent playing football at Stanford University.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $4.2 Million Homes in California
description: A three-bedroom home in La Jolla, a renovated retreat in Palm Springs and an Edwardian house in San Francisco.
content: This house is less than a five-minute walk from sandy beaches and the ocean, and less than 10 minutes from a stretch of La Jolla Boulevard with a coffee shop, a grocery store and a bakery specializing in bagels. It is about a five-minute drive from La Jolla Village and from the La Jolla Tide Pools, a popular place to catch a glimpse of crabs and other sea creatures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: Man Charged With Hate Crime After Destructive Break-In at Islamic Center
description: Jacob Beacher is accused of stealing a Palestinian flag and causing $40,000 in damage to religious artifacts at Rutgers University during the Eid-al-Fitr holiday.
content: A New Jersey man was charged on Monday with a federal hate crime after a Palestinian flag was stolen and $40,000 worth of damage was done to religious artifacts at an Islamic student center at Rutgers University during the Eid-al-Fitr holiday, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Monday Briefing
description: The implications of Israel’s attack on Iran.
content: After a week of tense internal deliberation and international appeals for calm, Israel struck an air defense system in Iran on Friday, according to Western and Iranian officials. Israel’s airstrike was the latest in an exchange of attacks between the countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Gold
title: Liz Truss Is Coming for America
description: She has seen the deep state up close and knows what needs to be done.
content: Liz Truss was the prime minister of Britain for 49 days in 2022, an interregnum between Boris Johnson and Rishi Sunak that was so short, it was outlasted by a lettuce. In the annals of British decline, she will be remembered for having been in office just three days when Queen Elizabeth II died and for her plan for an enormous and apparently unfunded tax cut, which she abruptly dropped after a run on the pound.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Israelis Prepare to Mark Passover, a Festival of Freedom, With Hostages Still in Gaza
description: Many Jews say they will adapt their Passover rituals around the Seder table this year to fit the somber mood of a country at war.
content: Many Israelis were in a somber mood on Monday as they prepared to usher in Passover, the Jewish festival of freedom, saying they would mark the holiday rather than celebrate it, with more than 130 hostages remaining in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Rothfeld
title: How Tabloids Used ‘Catch-and-Kill’ to Trade on Secrets of Celebrities
description: The term was coined by tabloid editors for buying the rights to stories for the purpose of ensuring the information never becomes public. Donald J. Trump was a beneficiary.
content: “Catch-and-kill” is a term coined by old-time tabloid editors for buying the exclusive rights to stories, or “catching” them, for the specific purpose of ensuring the information never becomes public. That’s the “killing” part.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: ‘Cabaret’ Review: What Good Is Screaming Alone in Your Room?
description: Eddie Redmayne and Gayle Rankin star in a buzzy Broadway revival that rips the skin off the 1966 musical.
content: Just east of its marquee, the August Wilson Theater abuts an alley you probably didn’t notice when last you were there, perhaps to see “Funny Girl,” its previous tenant. Why would you? Where the trash goes is not usually part of the Broadway experience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Huw Edwards, a Top BBC Anchor, Resigns After 40 Years
description: Mr. Edwards had been off the air since July, when he was accused of paying for sexually explicit images, and he cited medical reasons for his decision to quit.
content: Huw Edwards, one of the BBC’s highest-profile anchors and who was suspended last year over allegations of paying for explicit images, resigned from the broadcaster on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: What We Know About the Protests at Columbia University
description: Demonstrations outside the school gates have added to the upheaval, with protesters who appear unconnected to the university targeting Jewish students.
content: Columbia University is grappling with the fallout from its president’s promise to Congress that she would crack down on unsanctioned protests, and her decision to ask the police to clear an encampment on campus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Fawcett, Alan Blinder, Amanda Holpuch and Jacey Fortin
title: Dozens of Yale Students Arrested During Campus Protests
description: Demonstrators were rounded up Monday morning at an encampment set up in support of Columbia University protesters.
content: More than 40 people were arrested at Yale University on Monday during pro-Palestinian protests, as student-led demonstrations that shook Columbia University and other campuses last week spread to the center of the school’s community in New Haven, Conn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colbi Edmonds
title: Intruder Breaks Into Los Angeles Mayor’s Residence
description: The Getty House was broken into early Sunday through a smashed window, the police said. Mayor Karen Bass said she and her family were safe.
content: The Getty House in Los Angeles, the official residence of Mayor Karen Bass, was broken into early Sunday, the Los Angeles Police Department said. The police took the intruder into custody, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: FIFA Said to Be Close to TV Deal With Apple for New Tournament
description: The agreement would give the tech company worldwide rights for a monthlong World Cup-style competition between top teams set to take place next year.
content: FIFA, soccer’s global governing body, is close to an agreement with Apple that would give the tech company worldwide television rights for a major new tournament, a monthlong, World Cup-style competition for top teams that will be played for the first time in the United States next summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Christobek
title: What to Expect at the Trump Criminal Trial
description: The defendant is unique, but the basic structure and rhythms of the trial resemble every American prosecution.
content: Follow our live coverage of Trump’s hush money trial in Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: How an Ex-N.B.A. Player Is Diversifying Wine One Sip at a Time
description: As corporate diversity efforts fade out, Channing Frye and his Chosen Family Wines have taken an unpretentious grass roots approach, bringing wine to communities of color.
content: When Channing Frye retired in 2019 after 15 years as a solid power forward in the N.B.A., he was at loose ends. With no long-term plans, he said, he began to feel depressed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano
title: TikTok Faces E.U. Inquiry Over ‘Addictive’ Features
description: European officials threatened to fine TikTok and force it to remove some features, the latest regulatory challenge for the Chinese-owned social media app.
content: European Union regulators on Monday threatened to fine TikTok over potentially addictive features on a version of its app called TikTok Lite, which was released to work more smoothly on slower wireless networks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: U.K. Approves Bill That Would Send Asylum Seekers to Rwanda
description: Britain’s Parliament passed contentious legislation to allow the deportation of asylum seekers to the African country, a political victory for Prime Minister Rishi Sunak.
content: Britain’s Conservative government finally won passage of its flagship immigration policy on Monday, enshrining a Rwanda deportation bill that human-rights campaigners say is inhumane, immigration experts say is unworkable and legal critics say has corroded the country’s reputation for rule of law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Harold Goldberg
title: Game Reviews: Vibrant African Myths and an Undersea Satire
description: Precision is necessary in Tales of Kenzera: Zau, which brims with Bantu traditions. Through repetition, Harold Halibut demonstrates a subtle mastery of human nature.
content: The good vibes of respect and kindness are earnestly presented in wildly divergent but effective ways in the speedy Tales of Kenzera: Zau, brimming with ancient Bantu myths, and in Harold Halibut, a slow-moving science fiction story that leans on the friendship between a human and a fishlike alien.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Singer
title: Spurred by Teen Girls, States Move to Ban Deepfake Nudes
description: Legislators in two dozen states are working on bills, or have passed laws, to combat A.I.-generated sexually explicit images of minors.
content: Caroline Mullet, a ninth grader at Issaquah High School near Seattle, went to her first homecoming dance last fall, a James Bond-themed bash with blackjack tables attended by hundreds of girls dressed up in party frocks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: How Can I Dress to Look More Grown-Up?
description: A reader is tired of being mistaken for someone in her early 20s. Our fashion critic offers tips for dressing with sophistication.
content: It is true that, given society’s obsession with youth, the question of how to look older does not come up too often. But as you point out, looking young can be nearly as much of an issue as looking mature, given all of the unspoken prejudices about age on either end of the spectrum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Melania Trump Reappears, in Black
description: At the Log Cabin Republicans’ fund-raiser, the former first lady stepped into the campaign spotlight, just as her husband’s hush-money trial begins.
content: On Saturday, the day after the jury was impaneled for former President Donald J. Trump’s hush-money trial in New York, Melania Trump finally returned to the presidential campaign trail. The occasion: the Log Cabin Republicans’ fund-raiser at Mar-a-Lago, at which Mrs. Trump was the guest of honor and addressed the room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: regale
description: This word has appeared in 10 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word regale has appeared in 10 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 7 in “At 116, She Has Outlived Generations of Loved Ones. But Her Entire Town Has Become Family” by Soumya Karlamangla:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: Ukraine’s New Hope
description: How an aid package from the U.S. could affect the war.
content: You have probably read that the war in Ukraine is a stalemate. But conditions have changed in recent months — in Russia’s favor. It has captured more territory, and it seems likely to launch a larger offensive later this spring or summer. In the meantime, Ukraine’s ability to fight back has deteriorated since the U.S. largely stopped sending aid in December.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers and Jim Rutenberg
title: New Group Joins the Political Fight Over Disinformation Online
description: The group intends to fight what its leader, Nina Jankowicz, and others have described as a coordinated campaign by conservatives and their allies to undermine researchers who study disinformation.
content: Two years ago, Nina Jankowicz briefly led an agency at the Department of Homeland Security created to fight disinformation — the establishment of which provoked a political and legal battle over the government’s role in policing lies and other harmful content online that continues to reverberate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: Joel Breman, Who Helped Stop an Ebola Outbreak in Africa, Dies at 87
description: Part of a team flown in to fight the deadly virus in 1976, Dr. Breman also worked to stamp out tropical diseases like smallpox, malaria and Guinea worm.
content: Dr. Joel Breman, a specialist in infectious diseases who was a member of the original team that helped combat the Ebola virus in 1976, died on April 6 at his home in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: N.F.L. Draft and ‘Bridget Jones’ Marathon
description: Football players get their chance to play in the national league. HBO airs all three movies staring Renée Zellweger.
content: For TV viewers who still haven’t cut the cord, here is a selection of cable and network shows, movies and specials broadcasting Monday through Sunday, April 22-28. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang
title: A.I.-Generated Child Sexual Abuse Material May Overwhelm Tip Line
description: A report by Stanford researchers cautions that the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children doesn’t have the resources to help fight the new epidemic.
content: A new flood of child sexual abuse material created by artificial intelligence is threatening to overwhelm the authorities already held back by antiquated technology and laws, according to a new report released Monday by Stanford University’s Internet Observatory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag
title: How Hudson Yards Went From Ghost Town to Office Success Story
description: The vacancy rate at Hudson Yards’ office towers is considerably lower than in the rest of Manhattan, though its luxury housing and retail offerings have been less successful.
content: It was March 2019, and 13,000 people were on Manhattan’s West Side at a star-studded opening ceremony for the largest private real estate project in United States history: Hudson Yards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Review: ‘Grenfell’ Listens to the Survivors of a Towering Inferno
description: At St. Ann’s Warehouse, this documentary play about a London fire is blood-boiling and aggrieved.
content: The notion of creating a safe space for an audience to experience a work of theater tends to provoke the tough-guy purists, because it sounds like coddling. Shouldn’t the stage be a place of daring, unhampered by any content revelations that might spoil the surprise?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: For Biden, Aid Package Provides a Welcome Boost on the World Stage
description: The congressional breakthrough on security assistance to Ukraine and Israel will let the president finally deliver arms to match his words. But it could be only a temporary respite.
content: Finally, President Biden had good news to share with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine. When Mr. Biden picked up the telephone at his home in Wilmington, Del., to call Mr. Zelensky on Monday, the two rejoiced over the congressional breakthrough that will result in the first significant new U.S. military aid for Ukraine in 16 months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbie VanSickle
title: Eighth Amendment Features in Supreme Court Case on Homelessness
description: A group of homeless plaintiffs argue that local laws aimed at banning sleeping outside violated their constitutional rights. The city claims that’s not what the Eighth Amendment means.
content: At the core of the Supreme Court battle over a small Oregon town’s treatment of its homeless people is a narrow question: Does the Eighth Amendment’s prohibition on cruel and unusual treatment apply to a city’s efforts to crack down on public sleeping and camping?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: Homelessness Case Draws Unusual Alliances: Conservatives and California Democrats
description: As voters’ frustration has grown with sprawling tent encampments in public spaces, Democratic and Republican leaders alike have called for greater authority to ban such camping.
content: The Goldwater Institute and Gov. Gavin Newsom of California ordinarily have little in common. One is a conservative think tank in Arizona, the other a Democrat leading one of the nation’s most liberal states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: PEN America Cancels Literary Awards Ceremony Amid Gaza War Fallout
description: The event had been set for April 29, but weeks of escalating criticism of the organization’s response to the war had led nearly half of the prize nominees to withdraw.
content: The free expression group PEN America has canceled its 2024 literary awards ceremony following months of escalating protests over the organization’s response to the war in Gaza, which has been criticized as overly sympathetic to Israel and led nearly half of the prize nominees to withdraw.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review No. 1,038
description: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Travelli and Suhasini Raj
title: Modi Calls Muslims ‘Infiltrators’ Who Would Take India’s Wealth
description: The direct language used against the country’s largest minority was a contrast to the image Prime Minister Narendra Modi presents on the world stage.
content: Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Sunday called Muslims “infiltrators” who would take India’s wealth if his opponents gained power — unusually direct and divisive language from a leader who normally lets others do the dirtiest work of polarizing Hindus against Muslims.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan, Maggie Haberman and Nate Schweber
title: The Circus Trump Wanted Outside His Trial Hasn’t Arrived
description: With support from demonstrators in Lower Manhattan spotty so far, Donald Trump issued a call to “rally behind MAGA,” and suggested the poor turnout was a result of a plot against his supporters.
content: Donald J. Trump was evidently not happy with what he saw out the window of his chauffeured S.U.V. as he rode through Lower Manhattan on Monday morning for the beginning of opening arguments in his first criminal trial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Michael Gold
title: Inside Trump’s Complicated Relationship With Law Enforcement
description: The former president has put forth a law-and-order candidacy while also criticizing the legal system when it comes to himself and making exceptions for his supporters.
content: On Jan. 19, 2021, as part of a series of pardons on his last full day in office, President Donald J. Trump commuted the sentence of a man who had spent almost 30 years of a life sentence in federal prison for what prosecutors said was his role in the murder of an undercover police officer in upstate New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: A Passover Pleasure: Matzo Pizza
description: While matzo takes many forms during the holiday, some say it is most delightful when pizza-fied.
content: During Passover, Jews move culinary mountains with matzo: cheesy lasagna with layers of the unleavened bread instead of noodles; peanut and caramel brittle; homemade pasta; and even pizza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: Papua New Guinea Leader Criticizes Biden’s ‘Cannibals’ Comment
description: Twice last week, President Biden suggested without evidence that his uncle had been eaten by cannibals there after his plane went down off the New Guinea coast during World War II.
content: Prime Minister James Marape of Papua New Guinea has hit back at President Biden’s suggestion that his uncle, a U.S. serviceman whose plane went down in the Pacific Ocean off the coast of New Guinea during World War II, had been eaten by cannibals there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: Trump Can Be Grilled About Cases He Lost and Gag Order Violations
description: The judge’s ruling could play into Donald J. Trump’s decision on whether to testify in his own defense.
content: The judge in Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial ruled on Monday morning that prosecutors could ask the former president about a range of previous cases that he has lost, as well as past violations of gag orders, in the event that he decides to testify in his defense.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor and Troy Closson
title: Columbia University to Hold Classes Remotely After Weekend Protests
description: The campus has been shaken by pro-Palestinian demonstrations that have left some Jewish students fearing for their safety.
content: Columbia University announced early Monday that it would hold classes remotely, a move that highlighted worsening friction at the school after a wave of protests on campus over the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Elon Musk Wouldn’t Be the First Car Company Founder to Flame Out
description: The world is not always kind to visionaries with self-control issues.
content: Before there was Elon Musk, there was William Crapo Durant. Billy Durant, as he was known, built one of the world’s biggest makers of horse-drawn carriages, bought control of Buick, co-founded General Motors, was forced out of General Motors, co-founded Chevrolet, regained control of General Motors, speculated on stocks, lost control of General Motors a second time, started Durant Motors, went bankrupt in the Depression, opened a bowling alley, suffered a stroke and died penniless in 1947.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: Palestinian Baby Delivered After Mother Killed in Israeli Strike
description: The baby was born 10 weeks premature and weighed three pounds, a doctor said. Her father and sister also died.
content: Doctors in Gaza delivered a baby on Saturday from a Palestinian woman who had been killed alongside her husband and daughter in an Israeli strike in the city of Rafah, where more than one million people have fled during Israel’s war in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Rube Goldberg’s Greatest Machine Is His Legacy
description: Decades after Mr. Goldberg, a cartoonist, died, artists and engineers have found creative inspiration in his outlandish inventions.
content: What’s the simplest way to open a can? Faced with this question, most would suggest a can opener. The artist Rube Goldberg, however, believed the task could be better accomplished using a golf club, waltzing mice and a disgruntled pet dragon whose fire-breathing would light a welding torch positioned in front of the closed can. Simple.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Everton Seeks Alternative Buyer as Deal With 777 Partners Falters
description: With a proposed sale stalled seven months after it was announced, a financially strapped Premier League team is pursuing a backup plan.
content: Advisers for Everton, one of the oldest teams in English soccer and a founding member of the Premier League, have begun searching for an alternative buyer for the financially stricken club, according to people familiar with the decision who requested anonymity to discuss private talks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag
title: Trump and Attorney General Agree on Minor Changes to $175 Million Bond
description: Letitia James had asked a court to reject the bond that Donald J. Trump posted in his civil fraud case. A deal on Monday will keep the terms of the bond largely unchanged.
content: The New York attorney general’s office and representatives for Donald J. Trump agreed in court on Monday to slightly modify the terms of a $175 million bond posted by the former president in his civil fraud case after the state questioned the qualifications of the company that provided it and sought to have it rejected.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: April 22, 2024
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, April 22, 2024.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Roy
title: Crafting Shoes Never Meant to Be Walked In
description: In Venice, a coterie of craftspeople reinterpret Tod’s driving shoes.
content: Last week at the Venice Biennale, the milliner Giuliana Longo wore gold earrings in the shape of hats as she showed off a hat sculpture made of natural agave. Ms. Longo, who has worked as a milliner since 1969, said through a translator that she fell in love with hats because “if you wear a hat, you become a different person.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Claire Fu
title: The Chinese Site That Rewired Online Shopping
description: Pinduoduo appeals to people seeking deals and “downgraded spending,” as consumer purchasing in China has slowed recently amid economic rockiness.
content: When Pinduoduo, the Chinese discount shopping app, debuted nearly a decade ago, the tech giants Alibaba and JD.com dominated China’s e-commerce business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Obbie
title: A City Tries to Measure the Violence It’s Preventing
description: In Baton Rouge, a public safety experiment could help to answer a critical question: Do community efforts to reduce street violence work?
content: In Baton Rouge, a public safety experiment could help to answer a critical question: Do community efforts to reduce street violence work?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William B. Davis, Madison Dong, Judson Jones, John Keefe and Bea Malsky
title: Maps: Earthquakes Shake Eastern Taiwan
description: View the location of each quake’s epicenter and shake area.
content: View the location of each quake’s epicenter and shake area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Holder, Eric Schmitt and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: Ukraine’s Race to Hold the Line
description: The days of lightning battlefield breakthroughs may be over. With Russia preparing to make a big push, the Ukrainians can do little but dig in.
content: The days of lightning battlefield breakthroughs may be over. With Russia preparing to make a big push, the Ukrainians can do little but dig in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: Do You Know These Films Based on Great Biographies?
description: Try this short quiz to test your knowledge of books and their memorable movie adaptations.
content: Try this short quiz to test your knowledge of books and their memorable movie adaptations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Fawcett
title: Pro-Palestinian Protesters Block Intersection at Yale University
description: Protests continued at Yale University following the arrests of dozens of students at a pro-Palestinian encampment on the campus.
content: Protests continued at Yale University following the arrests of dozens of students at a pro-Palestinian encampment on the campus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich, Gabriel Blanco, Rebecca Suner and Claire Hogan
title: Trump Criminal Trial Day 5: Opening Statements and a Brisk Pace
description: Jonah Bromwich, a criminal justice reporter at The New York Times, gives the major takeaways from the opening statements and the first witness of Trump’s criminal trial in Manhattan. An earlier version of this video misstated that it’s the sixth day of the Trump hush-money trial. It is Day 5.
content: Jonah Bromwich, a criminal justice reporter at The New York Times, gives the major takeaways from the opening statements and the first witness of Trump’s criminal trial in Manhattan. An earlier version of this video misstated that it’s the sixth day of the Trump hush-money trial. It is Day 5.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Kelso and Meg Felling
title: Dozens of Yale Students Arrested as Campus Protests Spread
description: The police arrested students at a pro-Palestinian protest encampment at Yale University, days after more than 100 student demonstrators were arrested on the campus of Columbia University.
content: The police arrested students at a pro-Palestinian protest encampment at Yale University, days after more than 100 student demonstrators were arrested on the campus of Columbia University.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nailah Morgan
title: How a Displaced Gazan Collects Aid From Airdrops
description: Oday Abed, 30, rides his bike to the coast of northern Gaza in hopes of getting aid packages with essential items, like food and clothing, for his family who is staying at the Jabaliya refugee camp.
content: Oday Abed, 30, rides his bike to the coast of northern Gaza in hopes of getting aid packages with essential items, like food and clothing, for his family who is staying at the Jabaliya refugee camp.
source.name: The New York Times
